class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) CV profiles of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600. (b) Plots of log (<em>v</em>) vs log (<em>i</em>). (c) The contribution ratios of capacitances at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> and (d) at various scan rates.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">The values of b closing to 0.5 or 1.0 indicate the electrochemical diffusion or capacitive effect, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b shows the log(i) and log(v) curves of the MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 electrode with b values closing to 1, indicating the fast redox kinetics on the surface of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 electrode with capacitive effect, which may be related to its good performances at high current density [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">In order to further analyze the relationship between diffusion capacitance and pseudo-capacitance contribution, the processes can be described quantitatively according to the formula (Eq. 5),<span class="display"><span id="fd5" class="formula"><span class="label">(5)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">the total current contribution (i) is divided by k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> and k<sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>1/2</sup>, which indicated the capacitive control and diffusion control processes. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c shows that the pseudo-capacitance contribution reaches 89&nbsp;% when the sweep speed is 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>. The ratio gradually increases to about 93&nbsp;% when the scanning rate went up from to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>d). The high capacitance contribution may be due to the hierarchical <a href="/topics/engineering/nanomaterial" title="Learn more about nanostructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanostructure</a> with nanosheets self-assembly, which raises more surface active sites to hold more Na</span><sup>+</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">The galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT)was further used to estimate the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> during the charge and discharge (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. In GITT measurements, the variation of voltage response to time can be achieved by alternating pulses and relaxation. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5a</span></span></a> shows GITT curves of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 and MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-700 electrodes. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5b</span></span></a> shows the enlarged description of GITT data. The Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> can be achieved from equation (Eq. 6) [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>].<span class="display"><span id="fd6" class="formula"><span xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">M</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">M</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">In the formula, m<sub>B</sub>, V<sub>M</sub> and M<sub>B</sub><span><span> are the active substance mass, <a href="/topics/materials-science/density-specific-gravity" title="Learn more about molar volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar volume</a>, and </span><a href="/topics/engineering/molar-mass" title="Learn more about molar mass from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar mass</a>. τ and S represent the current pulse time and surface area. ΔE</span><sub>s</sub> and ΔE<sub>τ</sub> are the voltage changes associated with current pulse and constant current, respectively. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S5c–d</span></span></a><span><span> shows the relationship between <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion</a> </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusivity</a> and voltage during discharge and charging respectively. From the charge-discharge process, the value of LogD</span><sub>Na</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;for MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 is higher than that of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-700, indicating that MoTe<sub>2</sub><span>/C-6h-600 has better <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-kinetics" title="Learn more about diffusion kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion kinetics</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155"><span>To investigate the <a href="/topics/engineering/interfacial-resistance" title="Learn more about interfacial resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interfacial resistance</a> of the MoTe</span><sub>2</sub><span>/C electrodes, <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> tests of MoTe</span><sub>2</sub>/C-3h-600, MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-500, MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600, MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-700, and MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-9h-600 were evaluated after cycles. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a><span>, the <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-diagram" title="Learn more about Nyquist diagram from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist diagram</a> of the MoTe</span><sub>2</sub>/C electrode consists of a semicircle and a diagonal line. The semicircle in the mid-high frequency is induced by the charge transfer between the active material and the electrolyte. The observable diagonal line corresponding to Warburg impedance (Zw, in the low frequency region) represents Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion in the electrode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. EIS data are fitted using the equivalent circuit diagram in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>, R<sub>1</sub> is related to solution resistance (R<sub>s</sub>) and R<sub>2</sub> is related to R<sub>ct</sub>. CPE1 is related to the constant phase element of the R<sub>ct</sub>, Wo is related to the Warburg impedance. After fitting, the R<sub>ct</sub> values of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-3h-600, MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-500, MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600, MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-700, and MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-9h-600 electrodes are184.7Ω, 302.3&nbsp;Ω, 140.1&nbsp;Ω, 192.4&nbsp;Ω, and 245&nbsp;Ω, respectively. MoTe<sub>2</sub><span>/C-6h-600 electrode has the lowest impedance, which can effectively improve <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a>, reduce charge transfer impedance, and deliver higher electrochemical performance.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0160">The SEM images before and after cycling of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 and MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-700 are illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a> to identify the structure stability of electrodes. Before cycling, the two electrodes both have similar smooth surfaces. However, MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-700 displays many small and narrow cracks in the electrode plate after cycling. By contrast, MoTe<sub>2</sub><span>/C-6h-600 has almost no cracks in the electrodes after cycling, and the flower-like structure has good <a href="/topics/materials-science/mechanical-strength" title="Learn more about mechanical strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mechanical strength</a>, so that it can maintain its original appearance. Furthermore, TEM and HRTEM characterizations of MoTe</span><sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 after cycling are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>. Although it did not clearly display the flower like morphology probably due to the relatively complex components of electrode plates, the ultrathin nanosheets of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 were observed, suggesting the stable microstructures. The (112) and (004) crystal faces of MoTe<sub>2</sub> were observed with the lattice spacing of 0.27&nbsp;nm and 0.34&nbsp;nm, which is also corresponding to the mentioned mechanism analysis of reversible conversion reaction (equations <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd1" name="bfd1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd2" name="bfd2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a>)). Additionally, XPS characterizations of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 electrode plates before and after cycling show that the main characteristic peaks of each element are relatively close to the initial prepared product powder (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>), except for the shift of C–O bonds, which may be related to the addition of conductive carbon black in the electrode plates.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig7"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0272884224024258-gr7.jpg" height="604" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="cap0045"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0272884224024258-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0272884224024258-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0045"><p id="fspara0040"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. (a) Electrode diagram after cycles; SEM images of samples before (b, c) and after (d, e) cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0165">Considering the outstanding performances of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 in half cells, it was assembled into full cells based on the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) as cathode coupling to evaluate the applicability of MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a> displays the electrochemical performance and morphology of NVP cathode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>a shows the structural diagram of full cell (MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600//NVP). The full cell delivers an excellent 1st discharge capacitance of 186 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and a good reversible capacitance of 103 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>b). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>c shows the similar GCD curves to MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 half cell and the initial Coulombic efficiency reaches 97&nbsp;%. Furthermore, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig8" name="bfig8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>d exhibits a digital photo that the assembled MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600//NVP full cell powered an electronic gyroscope and Video S1 displays the related rotation scene.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig8"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0272884224024258-gr8.jpg" height="389" alt="Fig. 8" aria-describedby="cap0050"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0272884224024258-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (627KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (627KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0272884224024258-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0050"><p id="fspara0045"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. (a) Schematics of the full cell. (b) Cycling performance and (c) GCD profiles at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. (d) A digital photo that the application of full cell in an electronic gyroscope.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175">The following is the supplementary data related to this article.<span class="display"><span class="e-component e-component-mmc2" id="video"><span class="article-attachment u-margin-xs-bottom"><span class="video-player"><div 0-1.295-0.703-2.256-1.755-2.861 1.256 0.094 2.572 1.205 2.572 2.74 0 1.877-0.653 2.823-0.769 2.957 1.975-1.158 3.193-3.91 3.029-6.37 0.61 0.401 1.27 0.577 1.971 0.625 0.751 0.052 1.475-0.225 5.192c0.325 0 0.577 0.252 0.577 0.577s-0.252 0.577-0.577 0.577c-0.325 0-0.577-0.252-0.577-0.577s0.252-0.577 0.577-0.577zM0.553 5.385l-0.553 1.538h3.197c0.26-0.824 0.586-1.328 0.769-1.538h-3.413z"></path></svg><span class="able-clipped">Faster</span></div></div><div class="able-right-controls"><div role="button" tabindex="0" aria-label="Preferences" class="able-button-handler-preferences" aria-controls="ableMediaId_0-prefs-menu" aria-haspopup="menu" aria-expanded="false" data-prefs-popup="menu"><svg focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" viewBox="0 0 20 20"><path d="M18.238 11.919c-1.049-1.817-0.418-4.147 1.409-5.205l-1.965-3.404c-0.562 0.329-1.214 0.518-1.911 0.518-2.1 0-3.803-1.714-3.803-3.828h-3.931c0.005 0.653-0.158 1.314-0.507 1.919-1.049 1.818-3.382 2.436-5.212 1.382l-1.965 3.404c0.566 0.322 1.056 0.793 1.404 1.396 1.048 1.815 0.42 4.139-1.401 5.2l1.965 3.404c0.56-0.326 1.209-0.513 1.902-0.513 2.094 0 3.792 1.703 3.803 3.808h3.931c-0.002-0.646 0.162-1.3 0.507-1.899 1.048-1.815 3.375-2.433 5.203-1.387l1.965-3.404c-0.562-0.322-1.049-0.791-1.395-1.391zM10 14.049c-2.236 0-4.050-1.813-4.050-4.049s1.813-4.049 4.050-4.049 4.049 1.813 4.049 4.049c-0 2.237-1.813 4.049-4.049 4.049z"></path></svg><span class="able-clipped">Preferences</span></div><div role="button" tabindex="0" aria-label="Enter full screen" class="able-button-handler-fullscreen"><svg focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" viewBox="0 0 20 20"><path d="M0 18.036v-5q0-0.29 0.212-0.502t0.502-0.212 0.502 0.212l1.607 1.607 3.705-3.705q0.112-0.112 0.257-0.112t0.257 0.112l1.272 1.272q0.112 0.112 0.112 0.257t-0.112 0.257l-3.705 3.705 1.607 1.607q0.212 0.212 0.212 0.502t-0.212 0.502-0.502 0.212h-5q-0.29 0-0.502-0.212t-0.212-0.502zM8.717 8.393q0-0.145 0.112-0.257l3.705-3.705-1.607-1.607q-0.212-0.212-0.212-0.502t0.212-0.502 0.502-0.212h5q0.29 0 0.502 0.212t0.212 0.502v5q0 0.29-0.212 0.502t-0.502 0.212-0.502-0.212l-1.607-1.607-3.705 3.705q-0.112 0.112-0.257 0.112t-0.257-0.112l-1.272-1.272q-0.112-0.112-0.112-0.257z"></path></svg><span class="able-clipped">Enter full screen</span></div></div><div style="clear:both;"></div><ul id="ableMediaId_0-prefs-menu" class="able-popup" role="menu" style="display: none;"><li role="menuitem" tabindex="-1">Captions</li><li role="menuitem" tabindex="-1">Descriptions</li><li role="menuitem" tabindex="-1">Keyboard</li><li role="menuitem" tabindex="-1">Transcript</li></ul></div><div class="able-status-bar"><span class="able-timer"><span class="able-elapsedTime">0:00</span><span class="able-duration"> / 0:02</span></span><span class="able-speed" aria-live="assertive">Speed: 1x</span><span class="able-status" aria-live="polite">Paused</span></div></div><div role="alert" class="able-alert" style="display: none; top: 220px;"></div><div role="alert" class="able-screenreader-alert"></div></div></div></span><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0272884224024258-mmc2.mp4" target="_blank" download="" title="Download video (573KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download video (573KB)</span></span></span></a></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="espara0010"><span class="label">Video 1</span>. 2</p></span></span></span></span></div></section></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0180">In summary, hierarchical flower-like MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C composites with unique nanosheet self-assembly are synthesized by employing Mo-PDA as precursors through a concise and effective synthesis route combined chelation, preoxidation and tellurization. The as-synthesized MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C composites exhibit rich structure designability and morphology regulatability, which are beneficial for enhanced Na<sup>+</sup> storage. Specifically, MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600 electrode maintains a discharge capacitance of 290.7 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>&nbsp;at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles and 161.1 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>&nbsp;at 1.0&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 3000 cycles. Furthermore, the assembled MoTe<sub>2</sub>/C-6h-600//NVP full cell has an excellent reversible capacitance of 103 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles, indicating the promising practical applications. Although we have discussed many advantages of as-prepared MoTe<sub>2</sub><span>/C <a href="/topics/engineering/nanocomposite" title="Learn more about nanocomposites from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanocomposites</a>, there are still some limitations. For example, how to reduce the preparation temperature of materials will be beneficial for energy consumption management. In addition, it is necessary to further improve the capacitance of full cell to drive large electronic instruments instead of current small electronic devices.</span></div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185"><strong>Lifeng Zhang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization. <strong>Yaoxin He:</strong> Writing – original draft, Visualization, Data curation. <strong>Jiaxi Bai:</strong> Software, Methodology, Formal analysis. <strong>Fenghua Liu:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Robert Bradley:</strong> Software, Methodology. <strong>Weiping Wu:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Methodology. <strong>Xingang Kong:</strong> Funding acquisition, Formal analysis. <strong>Shouwu Guo:</strong> Visualization, Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0095" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0190">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0100" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Nitrogen-doped%20sheet%20VO2%20modified%20separator%20to%20enhanced%20long-cycle%20performance%20lithium-sulfur%20battery&amp;publication_year=2021&amp;author=L.%20Yang&amp;author=Y.%20Li&amp;author=Y.%20Wang&amp;author=Q.%20Li&amp;author=Y.%20Chen&amp;author=B.%20Zhong&amp;author=X.%20Guo&amp;author=Z.%20Wu&amp;author=Y.%20Liu&amp;author=G.%20Wang&amp;author=Y.%20Song&amp;author=W.%20Xiang&amp;author=Y.%20Zhong" 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (2)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775325008833"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Scalable solvent-free preparation of micro silicon based composite anodes with dual interface protections for stable cycling lithium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Power Sources</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Balancing the high specific capacity and cycling durability of silicon based composite anodes is one of the key focuses in developing the next generation of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with high-energy density. The selections of micro silicon raw materials and carbon material coating strategies are beneficial for reducing costs and large-scale preparation. However, the simplification of the preparation process remains a significant challenge, particularly how to avoid the use of solvents. Herein, we reported a preparation strategy with the hot pressing using micro silicon, asphalts and graphite as raw materials, where asphalts can not only effectively encapsulate micro silicon without any solvents, but also provide dual interface protections combined with graphite. The as-prepared μmSi@C/G-1 delivers enhanced Li<sup>+</sup> storage performance, which exhibits discharge capacities of 497 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles and 430 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.5&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 300 cycles, suggesting good rate, capacity and cycling durability.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352492824025492"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Flexible Ni&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;S&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; anodes confined by multiple and porous carbon conductive pathways boost sodium storage performances</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Materials Today Communications</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0060">Textile-based batteries are promising candidates as the power sources of wearable electronic devices. Despite high theoretical capacities, nickel sulfides are restricted by structure strain and sluggish reaction kinetics as anodes for sodium-ion batteries. Herein, Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub> derived from Ni-based metal-organic framework (Ni-MOF) precursor is in situ decorated on cotton textile, followed by polymerization and carbonization. Thus, porous N-doped carbon superstructure (NC) wrapped Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub>@C on carbon textile (CC/Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub>@C@NC) are constructed, which combines the synergistic effect of dual-carbon encapsulation and porous architecture. Therefore, the unique architecture can accommodate the volume expansion as well as facilitate the electron/ion transfer. When tested as binder-free flexible electrodes, the optimized CC/Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub>@C@NC-38 % presents 351.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 60 cycles and 220.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 1 A g<sup>−1</sup> over 100 cycles. Electrochemical impedance spectra of CC/Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub>@C@NC-38 % electrode reveals facilitated charge transfer and rapid ion diffusion, which is manifested by a moderate Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficient, provided by galvanostatic intermittent titration technique. Dominant capacitive behavior is verified, contributing to superior rate performance (232.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 2 A g<sup>−1</sup>). In addition, utilizing Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> as the cathode, full cell is developed, offering 820.5 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in the initial cycle and delivering a stable capacity of 175.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 60 cycles.</div></div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></section></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S0272884224024258"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">© 2024 Elsevier Ltd and Techna Group S.r.l. All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right u-padding-s-top"><aside class="RelatedContent u-clr-grey8" aria-label="Related content"><section class="RelatedContentPanel u-margin-s-bottom"><header id="recommended-articles-header" class="related-content-panel-header u-margin-s-bottom"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary related-content-panel-toggle is-up button-link-icon-right button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="true" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=recommended-articles:type=close"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text"><h2 class="section-title u-h4"><span class="related-content-panel-title-text">Recommended articles</span></h2></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></header><div class="" aria-hidden="false" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-header"><div id="recommended-articles" class="text-xs"><ul><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-block"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article0-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0272884224024106" title="Phase stability of W-containing high-entropy carbide with silicon addition at high temperatures"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Phase stability of W-containing high-entropy carbide with silicon addition at high temperatures</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Ceramics International, Volume 50, Issue 18, Part A, 2024, pp. 32007-32014</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Yuan</span> <span>Qin</span>, …, <span>Guo-Jun</span> <span>Zhang</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S0272884224024106/pdfft?md5=8723e28b691f962a3c8067addde1a4ff&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S0272884224024106-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow"     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
